summary: Brown rust (leaf rust) is a common fungal disease of wheat that reduces photosynthetic area and yield when severe.
cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia triticina. It develops under warm, humid weather and spreads via wind-dispersed spores.
symptoms: Small, round to oval orange-brown pustules on leaf surfaces that release powdery spores. Infected leaves may yellow and die prematurely.
spread: Wind-borne spores spread rapidly between fields and regions. Overwinters on volunteer wheat and crop residues in some climates.
treatment: Apply labeled fungicides when economic thresholds are met and weather favors disease development. Follow local extension recommendations.
prevention: Plant resistant varieties, remove volunteer wheat and grasses, rotate crops, and monitor disease forecasts to time interventions appropriately.
